prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my girlfriend she doesn’t need to make plans every time I want to game?
My girlfriend and I have been living together for 4 months now. We’ve been together for 3 years, and I’ve loved every minute of it and we absolutely adore each other.

When we first got together I gave up a lot of my free time for dates and other couple things like that. 

We would spend the night together sometimes. But when we would go home alone, to our respective houses. I would use that time to get my game time in.

Now flash forward, we live together and are obviously spending more time together. 

It all started a few weeks ago after work, when my buddy messaged me and asked me to get on and play Apex Legends, I say yeah, and tell my girlfriend I’m gonna play some games if she doesn’t mind. Up until that point we only used my Xbox as an entertainment system ( think Hulu, YouTube and Netflix.) 

I had previously taken a pretty long break from games and I didn’t expect this to be her reaction.

She said, it’s not fair for me to play games because she has nothing else to do while we play. I said, well you can watch me play jokingly, I thought she was kidding at first, but then she continued and said if I wanna make plans then to let her know so she can be busy while I’m busy. She also said she missed me. I told her we could have time for just us when I was done playing, and that it wasn’t a “plan.” I’m not going anywhere, I’ll be right here. I even told her we could talk while I played. But she didn’t want to have any of it. She just went to her sisters house for a few hours, and I proceeded to get some dubs.

Then, it became an argument we had 2-3 times. I even gave her advanced notice on an occasion or two but If she failed to make her plan she blamed it on me. So I told her ‘she didn’t need to go out every time, I’m busy. Just relax and chill on your phone or use my laptop.’ 

She’s the kinda girl who wants constant attention and I am fine with that, but I also want to chill with my friends online and play. 

AITA?

Tl;dr Girlfriend wants me to preplan my gaming time so she can make plans to go out. I said she doesn’t need to go out just because I wanna play games.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is about a guy who's living with his girlfriend. They've been together for three years and he's been doing a lot of gaming. When they first started dating, he gave up some of his free time for dates and stuff, but now that they live together, he wants to game with friends and she's upset because she feels like she has nothing to do when he plays.

He says when he told her he wanted to play Apex Legends, she didn't like it because she had nothing else to do. He offered for her to watch, but she wanted him to make plans so she could be busy. He told her she didn't need to go out, just relax or use his laptop. But she kept acting like it was his fault if she didn't have plans. He's asking if he's in the wrong.

Hmm. First, communication is key in relationships. The author mentioned that he gave her advanced notice sometimes, but she still felt like she had to make plans. Maybe he didn't consider that she might not just want to watch him play. Maybe she needs her own space or activities. But he's also trying to maintain his own hobbies, which is normal.

She went to her sister's house a few times when he was gaming. That could be her way of coping, but maybe it's making things tense. He's saying she's the type who wants constant attention, but he also wants his own time. It seems like a balance issue.

He says she blames him when she doesn't make plans, but maybe she's feeling neglected. The author's response of telling her she doesn't have to go out might be dismissive of her feelings. Maybe he should have asked how she felt instead of just assuming she can just relax. It's possible he's not considering her need for social activities or downtime, which is valid.

On the other hand, he's also entitled to his own time and interests. The problem is that their expectations aren't aligned. He thought gaming casually without planning was fine, but she wanted scheduled activities so she could have her own time. That mismatch might be the real issue. So he's not entirely wrong, but maybe he could have approached it with more empathy. However, the question is if he is in the wrong. Since he's defending his right to game without her having to make plans, but she's feeling that her needs aren't met, it's a bit of a gray area. But since he's the one adjusting his behavior, maybe he's not in the wrong. Alternatively, if he's not considering her emotional needs, he might be. But I'm leaning towards B, No, he's not in the wrong because both need some space.
